(2 Nephi 13:9)."The shew of their countenance doth witness against them." When Satan instructed Cain to make an unacceptable offering to the Lord, and it was rejected by Deity, "Cain was very wroth, and his countenance fell." His fallen countenance was very evident to the Lord and was, in fact, a witness against Cain's evil intentions; for "Cain loved Satan more than God." (Moses 5:18-22.)

None can hide their feelings, intentions, thoughts, or deeds from God. We either gather light to our countenance through righteousness or we diminish and darken our countenance through sin. Ultimately, our countenance will reflect the degree of eternal glory we will receive.

"To the wicked, who are filled with darkness, one may ask, 'Where is thy glory?' (Moses 1:12-14.) Yet the righteous 'shall shine forth in the kingdom of God' (Alma 40:25), and of them it will be said they are 'glorious beyond description [with a] countenance truly like lightning' (JS H 1:32)." (BICQ, 232-33.)
